3Physical Activity Neuroscience, Physical Activity Sciences Postgraduate Program - Salgado de Oliveira University, Niterói, Brazil Abstract We describe a succes sful tinnitus treatment case, with intensity and distress reduction, in patient submitted to bilateral 10Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) to dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC). Subjective tinnitus is the perception of sound in ear s or head when no corresponding external stimulus exists. Approximately 1 -2% of the population report severe tinnitus, with daily life impairment. S ham-controlled studies reveal benefits using rTMS in tinnitus, although improvement is moderate or temporary , indicating need for new strategies. Evidence that DMPFC is important in tinnitus pathophysiology make this area a promising target. A 51 year -old male patient with 4 - year history of treatment -resistant moderate bilateral tinnitus was treated with 20 sess ions of bilateral 10Hz DMPFC rTMS. Patient presented important reduction and sustained 4 month response in tinnitus loudness and annoyance, 24 point drop in tinnitus handicap inventory, visual analog scale reduction to zero and tinnitus loudness of 1dB, co mpared to baseline 15dB. Tinnitus treatment is hard and new alternatives are needed. To our knowledge, this is the first report using rTMS in DMPFC for tinnitus. In this protocol, important and sustained reduction of tinnitus annoyance and loudness was obt ained. This
case suggest this approach promising for treating tinnitus and is worth further investigation.

Key words: tinnitus, prefrontal cortex, transcranial magnetic stimulation Introduction In this report, we describe a case of success, with a reducti on in tinnitus intensity and distress, in a patient submitted to bilateral high frequency rTMS to the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC).

Subjective tinnitus is characterized by the perception of sound in the ears or head when there is no corresponding external stimulus. About 5 to 15% of the adult population perceive these sounds chronically. Approximately 1 -2% of the general population report severe tinnitus, associated with impact in daily life. Despite the great amount of literature concerning tinnit us treatment, there are still no evidence -based established treatments for curing tinnitus or for effectively reducing its intensity [1].

Some Sham -controlled studies revealed beneficial effects using repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in the treatment of tinnitus. But, still, results show only moderate or temporary improvement and high variability between individuals. New strategies, focusing different brain areas related to tinnitus should be tested and evaluated in new studies[2 -3]. The subcallosal area, containing the medial prefrontal (dorsal and ventral) and anterior cingulate cortices, has been implicated in tinnitus pathophysiology, according to neuroimaging studies, making this area a potential target for tinnitus treatment with rT MS [4 -5]. The use of DMPFC rTMS has been described in the treatment of other disorders and, recently, in patients with major depression in borderline personality disorder, a report of three cases, with successful results [6]. Given the scientific backgrou nd, we experimented a new rTMS protocol with promising results as described in the following case.

Case Presentation Patient provided written informed consent. The study was approved by ethics committee (protocol CAEE 48853015.6.0000.5263). A 51 year -old caucasian male, engineer, presenting continuous, bilateral, symmetric tinnitus for 4 years, already treated with pharmacological interventions and tinnitus retraining therapy with no reduction in

tinnitus intensity or annoyance . The tinnitus worsened wit h stress and in silent environment. The patient had no dizziness, hearing loss or fulness in the ears. He had good health, didn't use any medication regularly and had no complaints of pain in the head or neck. Otolaryngological clinical exam was normal and so were audiometric and laboratory tests.

The Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI) v 5.0 revealed no concomitant psychiatric disorders. The symptom was measured using the Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI) and visual analog scale (VAS), tin nitus pitch matching (PM), loudness matching (LM) and minimal masking level (MML) at baseline, 2 weeks, 1 and 4 months after treatment.

The rTMS protocol consisted of 10 Hz stimulation at 120% of the resting motor threshold of the extensor hallucis longu s. Each session of 10 Hz stimulation applied 3000 pulses to each hemisphere non -simultaneous (6000 pulses total), a duty cycle of 5 seconds on and 10 seconds off, for a total stimulation time of 30 minutes, 5 times a week, consecutively, for 4 weeks, over bilateral DMPFC (Fz electrode site in the 10/20 International EEG system, corresponding to the 25% of the nasion -inion distance ), using the fluid -cooled figure 8 coil (Neurosoft, Neuro -MS/D device). Baseline, 2 -weeks, 1 and 4 -month follow -up THI and VAS s cores and tinnitus loudness and MML are presented in Table 1. At baseline the patient had moderate tinnitus, grading 38 in THI and 7 in VAS. After 4 weeks of rTMS, the patient effectively responded to treatment, as indicated by a drop greater than 20 point s in the THI, a reduction of VAS to 0, and MML and tinnitus loudness reduction to 1dB, compared to 18 and 15dB, respectively, at baseline. There were no reported side effects after rTMS. At 4 months the patient displayed sustained remission.

Discussion To our knowledge, this is the first report of the use of rTMS targeting the DMPFC to treat tinnitus. The treatment of tinnitus is notoriously hard and new alternatives are ghastly needed. In our report, the patient presented an important and sustained reduc tion of his tinnitus after bilateral DMPFC -rTMS. Our findings suggest that rTMS targeting the medial prefrontal cortex, specifically the DMPFC, may represent a safe and tolerable therapeutic alternative for tinnitus treatment. E vidence shows that tinnitus patients exhibit

significantly less gray matter (GM) volume in ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) compared to control participants as well as in DMPFC [4]. Studies identified that the GM reductions in the DMPFC correlated directly with the percentage o f time participants were aware of their tinnitus. Thus, patients with bigger cortical sulci were aware of their tinnitus more often than those with DMPFC gyrificiation similar to control participants, suggesting that this area may play an important role in tinnitus [5]. In a study using voxel - based morphometry, there was evidence of significant volume loss in the subcallosal area (which includes the DMPFC) in tinnitus patients [7]. Thus, t he subcallosal area may be considered as a major hub linking limbic -affective systems with thalamo -cortical system. The first clinical study with tinnitus patients stimulated in deeper brain areas was published by Vanneste et al. [8] applying double -cone -coil (DCC) rTMS to the medial frontal cortex of 78 patients, showin g improvement depending on the frequency of the stimulation. A second study with 73 patients was published reporting differences between single session and repeated sessions of 1Hz DCC TMS prefrontal stimulation (anterior cingulate cortex) for tinnitus tre atment. Both single sessions and multiple sessions suppressed tinnitus distress and intensity transiently. Multiple sessions generated a higher suppression effect in more patients when comparing to single session [9]. A randomized, double -blind pilot tri al with 40 patients suffering from chronic tinnitus compared mediofrontal stimulation with DCC, (10Hz) combined with left temporo -parietal stimulation with figure -of-eight -coil (1Hz) to left dorsolateral - prefrontal -cortex stimulation with figure -of-eight -coil (10Hz) combined with temporo - parietal stimulation with figure -of-eight -coil (1Hz). The combination of mediofrontal/temporoparietal -rTMS failed to show better outcome when compared to the group dorsolateral prefrontal/temporo -parietal[10].

Conclusion The impressive result of this case, with important and sustained reduction of tinnitus annoyance and loudness in a previously treated patient, suggests that rTMS of the DMPFC is a promising approach for the treatment of tinnitus and is worth further investi gation. Coil placement is simple and can be accurately achieved without MRI guidance. Even though the DMPFC lies 3 -4cm deep, the figure of eight coil can stimulate this area when the motor threshold of the extensor hallucis longus is found [11]. Given this report, it can now be said that r andomized sham -controlled trials to assess the efficacy
of DMPFC -rTMS in tinnitus are important and could drastically improve patient's treatment safely and effectively.

Abstract Objective : Tinnitus is the perception of sound in ears or head without corresponding exter nal stimulus. Despite the great amount of literature concerning tinnitus treatment, there are still no evidence -based established treatments for curing or for effectively reducing tinnitus intensity. Sham -controlled studies revealed beneficial effects usin g repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS). Still, results show moderate, temporary improvement and high individual variability. S ubcallosal area (ventral and dorsomedial prefrontal and anterior cingulate cortices) has been implicat ed in tinnitu s pathophysiology. Our objective is to e valuate the use of bilateral, high frequency dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) rTMS in treatment of chro nic subjective tinnitus. Design : Randomized placebo controlled, blinded clinical trial. Twenty sessions of bilateral, 10Hz rTMS at 120% of resting motor threshold of extensor hallucis longus was applied over the DMPFC. Fourteen patients underwent sham rTMS and 15 were submitted to active stimulation . Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI), visual analog scale (VAS) a nd tinnitus loudness matching were obtained at baseline and on follow up visits. The impact of intervention on outcome measures was evaluated using a regression model for longitudinal data. Results : 11.52 point reduction in THI scores is observed in active group (95% IC: -23.1 a 0.0; p=0.05). Tinnitus loudness matching also shows advantage in active group, reduction of 4.46 dB (95% CI: -9.60 a 0.68 dB, p=0.09). Conclusion : Tinnitus treatment with high frequency, bilateral, DMPFC rTMS was effective in reduci ng tinnitus annoyance measured by THI and tinnitus loudness when compared to sham stimulation.
Key words: Tinnitus; repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation; rTMS; dorsomedial prefrontal cortex Approved by the Brazilian Clinical Trials Registration (Re BEC) under the number RBR -

Introduction Subjective tinnitus is characterized by the perception of sound in the ears or head when there is no corresponding external stimulus. About 5 to 15% of the adult population perceive these sounds chronically. Ap proximately 1 -2% of the general population report

severe tinnitus, associated with significant impact in daily life (Jastreboff & Hazell 1993; Onishi et al. 2018) . Despite the great amount of literature concerning tinnitus treatment, there are still no evidence -based established treatments for curing tinnitus or for effectively reducing its intensity (Tunkel et al. 2014) .

Modern neurophysiological and neuroimaging techniques helped to understand the abnormal functioning of the central nervous system in patients with chronic subjective tinnitus (Lanting et al. 2009; Schlee et al. 2008; De Ridder et al. 20 13). Tinnitus is associated with functional changes in central auditory and non -auditory pathways, as well as dysfunctional connectivity between these areas (Møller 2011; Eggermont & Roberts 2012; Leaver et al. 2011; Seydell -Greenwald et al . 2012) . Changes in activity in temporal, frontal, parietal and limbic areas associated with tinnitus seem to reflect these pathologic abnormalities (Seydell -Greenwald et al. 2012; Leaver et al. 2016a; Rauschecker et al. 2010; Raus checker et al. 2015; Landgrebe et al. 2009; Maudoux et al. 2012; Mirz 2000; Ueyama et al. 2013) .

Sham -controlled studies revealed beneficial effects using repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in the treatment of tinnitus (Plewnia et al. 2007; Rossi et al. 2007; Smith et al. 2007; Lehner et al. 2016; Langguth et al. 2014; Kreuzer et a l. 2011; Folmer et al. 2015) . But, still, results show only moderate or temporary improvement and high variability between individuals. New strategies, focusing different brain areas related to tinnitus should be tested and evaluated in new studies (Kreuzer et al. 2011; Folmer et al. 2015) . The subcallosal area, containing the me dial prefrontal (dorsal and ventral) and anterior cingulate cortices, has been implicated in tinnitus pathophysiology, according to neuroimaging studies, making this area a potential target for tinnitus treatment with rTMS (Leaver et al. 2016a; Seydell - Greenwald et al. 2012; Leaver et al. 2011; Rauschecker et al. 2010; Leaver et al. 2016b) . The use of dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) rTMS has been described in the treatment of other disorder s, as major depression, with successful result (Downar & Daskalakis 2013; Bakker et al. 2015) .

Given the need for new tinnitus treatment and to optimize tinnitus rTMS protocols, considering the involvement of the medi al frontal cortices in tinnitus pathophysiology and based on the successful results with DMPFC rTMS to treat depression, the objective
of our study is to evaluate the use of bilateral, high frequency DMPFC rTMS in the treatment of chronic subjective tinnit us.
Materials and Methods:

A randomized placebo controlled, blinded clinical trial was conducted to evaluate the effects of bilateral, high frequency rTMS over the DMPFC on the treatment of chronic subjective tinnitus from January 2018 until December 2018 . The study was approved by the local ethics committee under the number CAEE 48853015.6.0000.5263 and registered and approved by the Brazilian Clinical Trials Registration (ReBEC) under the number RBR -748nrs. All patients signed a written informed consent before entering the trial. Sample and baseline evaluation:

A total of 48 patients were accessed to be included in the study. Eight of these did not meet the inclusion criteria and four did not want to participate for different reasons. The inclusion crit eria were as follows: patients from both genders with age ranging 20 - 80 years, diagnosis of tinnitus for at least 3 months and for 5 years at the most, with moderate severity (a minimum of 38 points in the Tinnitus Handicap Inventory), without associated p sychiatric disorders, according to DSM -V. Hearing had to be normal or sensorineural hearing loss compatible with age (age -adjusted, not more than 5 dB below the 10% percentile according to DIN EN ISO 7029) (Anon 2017; Valiente et al. 2015) . Exclusion criteria were: conductive hearing loss (outer and middle ear disease), objective tinnitus, somatossensory tinnitus, patients taking medication acting in the central nervous system, othe r current tinnitus treatment, contra indications for rTMS. Patients could not have been submitted to rTMS to ensure blinding of the study.

Thirty six patients were randomized, using a computer generated randomization list in Microsoft Excel®•, to enter th e study. Seven patients dropped out in different stages of the study. Our final sample was composed of 29 patients, between 47 and 78 years of age, randomized into two groups: sham and active. Fourteen patients underwent sham stimulation (group 0) and 15 w ere submitted to active rTMS stimulation (group 1). A baseline visit was performed 7 days before the beginning of rTMS sessions. During this visit patients underwent a full otolaryngology appointment, answered tinnitus scales (Tinnitus Handicap Inventory – THI and the visual analog scale on tinnitus annoyance – VAS), in order to evaluate tinnitus severity; completed the Mini Neuropsychiatric

Interview (MINI v5.0) to exclude psychiatric disorders and were submitted to a complete audiometric exam (bone and ai r conduction tonal and vocal audiometry) and tinnitus pitch matching, loudness matching and minimal masking level measurement to estimate tinnitus parameters (Momensohn -Santo, T.M.; Russo 2013; Henry & Meikle 2000; Mohan et al. 2016) .
The rTMS protocol:

The rTMS pro tocol consisted of 10 Hz stimulation at 120% of the resting motor threshold of the extensor hallucis longus (defined as the minimal intensity to move the hallucis longus five out of ten times, when stimulated). Each session of 10 Hz stimulation applied 300 0 pulses to each DMPFC (Fz electrode site in the 10/20 International EEG system, corresponding to the 25% of the nasion -inion distance ) (Mir-Moghtadaei et al. 2016) , non -simultaneously (6000 pulses total), a duty cycle of 5 seconds on and 10 seconds off, for a total stimulation time of 30 minutes, 5 times a week, co nsecutively, for 4 weeks, using the fluid -cooled figure 8 coil (Neurosoft, Neuro -MS/D device). The sham group received the same protocol using a placebo figure of eight coil. The coil was supported over the skull using a mechanical arm (Neurosof t-Equipamen tos Médicos, Brasil – Rua das Folhagens, 364 Campo Grande MS, Brazil ) and the patients were seated comfortably in a reclining chair.
Assessment and follow up:

The tinnitus scales (THI and VAS) and tinnitus measures (pitch and loudness matching and minim al masking level measure) were obtained at baseline and on follow up visits at 1 week, 2, 4 and 16 weeks after the end of the 4 weeks of rTMS treatment. Tinnitus measures were performed in a sound proof booth. Pitch matching was obtained using sounds from 250 to 12500Hz and loudness was measured in a 1dB stepwise increase from the patients hearing threshold for the specific tinnitus pitch until the intensity was the same as that of the tinnitus. Loudness was measured in the contralateral ear in cases of uni lateral tinnitus or contralateral to the worse tinnitus side in bilateral asymmetric cases. For bilateral symmetric tinnitus and hearing we always measured using the sound on the right ear (Henry 2016; Henry & Meikle 2000) . Minimal masking level was obtained on the opposite ear of that used for loudness and the intensity desired was when
the minimal sound necessary to completely mask the tinnitus was achieved. All measures were performed and confirmed t hree times and an arithmetic mean was obtained for the final result.

Statistical Analysis The distribution of the socio -demographic variables were calculated in both groups (active and sham) to describe the sample and to evaluate the balance achieved by randomization.

The impact of the intervention on the three outcomes of interest (THI, tinnitus loudness and VAS) was evaluated using a regression model for longitudinal data (repeated measures) using the information collected from baseline and from the fo ur follow up visits after the end of treatment (1,2,4 and 16 weeks) using Stata 14.0 statistic package. The results were considered statistically significant with p values ≤ 0.05 , and of borderline significance when the p -values were between 0.06 and 0.10 . The d -Cohen for the effect size was calculated to evaluate the difference between the groups using the measures from the last follow up evaluation, at 16 weeks. Results:
The final sample was composed of 29 patients as demonstrated in Figure 1 (CONSORT Flow chart).

Comparing the THI scores betwe en the two groups, an 11.52 point reduction is observed in favor of the active rTMS group (95% IC: -23.1 a 0.0; p=0.05) , controlling for gender and age . Figure 2 shows the smooth ed trajectorie s of the scores for both groups . An estimate of d -Cohen (“effect -size”) using the comparison between the mean values of the last follow up visit, at 16 weeks after the end of the treatment , was 0.88, and can be interpreted as a strong effect.

The ana lysis of tinnitus loudness matching also shows advantage in favor of the active group , with a reduction of 4. 46 dB ( 95% CI: -9.60 a 0.68 dB, p=0.09) , data adjusted for gender and age . Figure 3 shows the smoothed trajectories of the values for both groups.

The d -Cohen (“effect -size”) estimate, using the comparison between the mean values of the last follow up visit (16 weeks after end of the rTMS sessions) was 1. 04, which can be interpreted as a strong effect.

As for tinnitus annoyance, measured by the visual analog scale (VAS), the data show no statistical ly significant difference between the active and sham groups ( -0.95 95% IC: -2.21 a 0.30, p=0.13), even when adjusted for gender and age . Attention should be made to the great variability between indi viduals on these scores. For a mean reduction of -0.95, the standard deviation was 0.64. These findings are exposed on figure 4.
Discussion:

This is the first study to evaluate the effects of rTMS delivered to the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex. The re sults of our study show benefit with the use of bilateral, 4 week long, 10Hz DMPFC rTMS for the treatment of tinnitus. A significant reduction of the THI scores (p=0.05) in the active group and a borderline significant reduction of tinnitus loudness (p=0.0 9), with a strong effect size, on both measures, were observed. Despite the optimistic results regading rTMS to treat tinnitus (Folmer et al. 2015; Mennemeier et al. 2013; Langguth et al. 2007; Kleinjung et al. 2005) , the studies show a great variability in indivi dual responses to treatment as well as moderate benefits. Literature suggests optimizing protocols and testing new strategies to be used clinicaly (Kreuzer et al. 2011; Folmer et al. 2015) .

Our study uses a different rTMS protocol based on the evidence of the envolvement of the medial prefrontal cortices in tinnitus pathophysiolog y and on studies using rTMS to treat depression using longer treatment periods (4 -6weeks), with more than 1000 pulses per session and intensity higher than 100% of the motor threshold, which

can increase significantly the number of responders (Berlim et al. 2013b; Berlim et al. 2013a) and stimulating the DMPFC with a figure of eight coil (Downar & Daskalakis 2013; Bakker et a l. 2015; Mir -Moghtadaei et al. 2016) (Deng et al. 2014) . Many studies using rTMS to treat tinnitus have used low frequency stimulation protocols on the temporoparietal cortex (TPC), 5 to 10 sessions, and a reduction in tinnitus severity and annoyance could be observed when compared to sham stimulation (Plewnia et al. 2007; Rossi et al. 2007; Smith et al. 2007) . May et al (May et al. 2007) demonstrated, in neuroimaging studies, that low frequency TPC rTMS is capable of producing deep brain changes in functionaly connected auditory and non auditory areas. In that way, the benefit of superficial stimulations could be also happening because of their aditional deep brain effect. Langguth et al also observed alteration of cortical excitability in low frequency rTMS on the TPC, sugesting improvement in of subcortical inhibitory fu nction (Langg uth et al. 2007) . Folmer et al (Folmer et al. 2015) in a randomized clinical trial also found benefit using 10 sessions of 1Hz rTMS on the TPC in tinnitus severity with a sustained response after 26 weeks of follow up, like our results, with a sustained benefit. Kleinjung et al also demonstrated a highly significant improvement in tinnitus s cores after 1Hz rTMS over the auditory cortex with benefits remaining up to 6 months after treatment (Kleinjung et al. 200 5).

Some other studies showed no benefit in tinnitus severity after low frequency rTMS on the TPC. Piccirillo et al conducted two randomized controlled studies, the first protocol consisted of 10 sessions and no significant different was found when copai red to sham (Duddy et al. 2011) . The second protocol prolonged the treatment sessions for 20 and still results weren´t different between active and sham groups (Piccirillo et al. 2013) . A recent multicentric study by Landgrebe et al. revealed no benefit after 1Hz rTMS sessions. This randomized controlled trial evaluated 167 patients.

The limited results obtained in TPC rTMS studies opened a way to combined stimulation areas, specially a combination of low frequency TPC rTMS and high frequency left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) or low frequency right DMPFC. Kreuzer et al found that aditional right DLPFC low frequency, associated with TPC rTMS seemed pr omissing but there was no sham group in the study and a low effect size (Kreuzer et al. 2011) . De Ridder et al stimulated only the right DLPFC with 1 Hz and found benefits on tinnitus reduction after 10 sessions. Langguth et al, Lehner et al and

recently Formanek et al studied different superficial stimulated protocols in TPC and DLPFC and found no reductions in tinnitus measures (Formánek et al. 2018; Langguth et Despite the benefits demonstrated in some studies there was still a need for new protocols to establish a clinical indication for rTM S in the treatment of tinnitus. Tinnitus patients are very heterogeneous and tinnitus pathophysiology is quite complex as it involves many central areas and connections. The existing studies use very different protocols, inclusion criteria, patients charac teristics and outcome measures, making them difficult to be compared.

Stimulations of deeper brain areas arised as different protocols that could optimize results on tinnitus patients. Studies using stimulation of these deeper brain areas, the medial pref rontal cortices, are more comparable to our study. Vanneste et al. (Vanneste et al. 2011) placed a double cone coil (DCC) over the medial frontal cortex (1.5 cm anterior to one -third of the distance from the nasion inion) and tested different stimulation frequencies to observe the best response on tinnitus perception and distress. The presence of a control procedure (ie, placebo effect) was tested at the frequencies that yielded maximal tinnitus suppression rates. Low frequency fr ontal rTMS with the DCC im proved both tinnitus perception and tinnitus distress tra nsiently, but not the higher frequencies. In contrast to Vanneste´s study, our study found good results, with reduction of tinnitus annoyance and loudness, using high frequency rTMS and a figure of e ight coil. Kreuzer et al (Kreu zer et al. 2015) investigated a combined stimulation protocol in a double blind randomized trial using high frequency (10Hz) rTMS at the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) with DCC followed by low frequency (1Hz) rTMS at the left TPC using a figure of eight coil. They compaired this group with a second group submitted to 1Hz rTMS at the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex followed by 1Hz TPC rTMS, there was no placebo group. The study failed to show a better outcome for the deep brain stimulation group. Unlike our results, which demontrated better results when stimulating deep cortical areas when compaires to placebo.

The results of our study are relevant as they demonstrated the effectiveness of rTMS in the treatment of our tinnitus patients, although some limitations have to be pointed out. The small number of patients enrolled is one limitation, as is the relatively short follow up period of 16 weeks. Considering that one of the inclusion criteria of this
study was that tinnitus had to be present for less than five years, the results cannot assure that rTMS is effective for patients with more chronic tinnitus.
We believe rTMS is a promissing treatment modality for tinnitus patients, and future studies could investigate specific protocols for different tin nitus subgroups.
Conclusion:

Tinnitus treatment with high frequency (10Hz), bilateral, dorsomedial prefrontal cortex rTMS was effective in reducing tinnitus annoyance measured by the Tinnitus Handicap Inventory and tinnitus loudness when compared to sham stimulation. References:

4.6) Estudo 6: Artigo submetido para publicação The effects of mirtazapine on tinnitus in patients with panic disorder Patricia Ciminellia,1 – Otolaryngologist – corresponding author patriciaciminelli@gmail.com Sergio Machadob – Neuroscientist – secm80@gma il.com Antonio Egidio Nardia – MD, PhD, Psychiatrist, Full professor of psychiatry – antonioenardi@gmail.com

a Laboratory of Panic and Respiration (LABPR), Institute of Psychiatry (IPUB), Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Brazil. Rua Venceslau Brás, 71 Botafogo, Rio de Janeiro – RJ, Brazil 22290 -140 bPhysical Activity Neuroscience, Psysical Activity Sciences Postgraduate Program, Salgado de Oliveira University, Niterói, Brazil. Rua Mal. Deodoro, 217 - Bloco A - Centro, Niterói – RJ, Brazil 24030-060
Abstract:

Tinnitus is described as a sound perceived in the ears or head that is not generated by an outside source. Depression and anxiety are very common in tinnitus patients, prevalence can be as high as 80% and antidepressants are commonly pres cribed to minimize these comorbid conditions and reduce tinnitus impact on quality of life . Although tinnitus is a very prevalent symptom and impacts patient ´s quality of life in a significant way, there are still no FDA approved drug s to treat tinnitus. The objective of our study is to describe a successful reduction on tinnitus annoyance in patients with panic disorder (PD) and tinnitus treated with mirtazapine . Fourteen patients were included in our final sample, 7 male and 7 female. All patients were ev aluated at baseline, 1 2 weeks and 3 years after the beginning of mirtazapine. Scales and outcomes used were the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD), the Clinical Glo bal Impression Scale (CGI -S), the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) and the number of panic att acks. The total treatment with mirtazapine varied from 27 to 36 months (mean SD 32.2/3.7). A statistically s ignificant decrease in the

tinnitus after the beginning of the panic disorder. The decrease in all the symptoms were homogeneous and sustained for 3 years, when th e last follow up visit was performed. The role of central pathways involved in chronic tinnitus have been well described. Involvement of not only the auditory central pathways but also the limbic system in the generation and maintenance of tinnitus is und oubtful (10–12,22 –24). Treatment approaches capable of modulating the central nervous system seem to be the most effective for tinnitus patients. But, despite the knowledge we h ave, until now, there is no effective treatment to cure tinnitus (2,20) .

The literatur e regarding tinnitus is very consistent in demonstrating its strong association with psychiatric disorders, mainly anxiety and depression. Langguth et al described the importance of anxiety and depression as predictors of tinnitus severity, being highly re levant in tinnitus diagnosis and prognosis. Studies describe a possible shared neurobiological pathway influencing the development of both depression and anxiety and tinnitus. Co-morbid mental disorders are likely to be the most important factors affecting the disability and suffering of tinnitus patients. Many tinnitus patients have experienced a certain degree of anxiety and depression prior to the onset of the symptom. However, tinnitus can increase the severity of existing psychological disorders or ten dencies (25). Many studies found a high prevalence of tinnitus patients with associated psychiatric disorders, most frequently anxiety and somatoform disorders and often personality disorder s (4,5,7,8,26) . Zoger et al also found 62% of lifetime depression and 45% of anxiety in tinnitus patients (3).

Antidepressants are probably the most commonly prescribed medications for tinnitus patients.. These drugs seem to work better in tinnitus patients with associated anxiety and/or depression, in patients with more severe tinnitus and in those patients treated for longer periods of time with adequate doses of medications (18,19) . These results are in accordance with our study, our patients were tr eated for a long period with adequate doses of mirtazapine and improvement in both tinnitus and panic were significant and sustained.

Some studies have evaluated the effects of antidepressants in treatment of tinnitus. Paroxetine has been tested in patien ts with tinnitus, tinnitus and associated anxiety and tinnitus with depression and anxiety. The latest group showed the best results, changes in tinnitus were strongly correlated with changes in both depression and anxiety. This drug

seems to be effective in the treatment of distressed tinnitus patients with depression and anxiety, reducing both psychiatric symptoms and tinnitus severity (27) . Another study using paroxetine in no ndepressed tinnitus patients showed no benefits and significant side effects (28) . A study using vestipiant with paroxetine and another group using vestipiant alone for tinnitus showed no efficacy in the reduction of the symptom (29). In a double -blind, placebo -controlled study involving subjects with severe tinnitus and severe depression, nortriptyline significantly reduced depression scores, tinnitus disability scores and tinnitus loudness relative to placebo (30). The results suggest that nortriptyline is effective in reducing tinnitus loudness and severity in seve rely depressed tinnitus patients, but has less benefit in non -depressed subjects.

A study using sertraline in tinnitus patients with depression and anxiety revealed it to be more effective than placebo in reducing tinnitus severity (p=0,024) and loudness (p=0,014) after a 16 week follow up. There was a significant correlation between tinnitus reduction and improvement in depression and anxiety symptoms. The study concluded that sertraline was more effective than placebo in the treatment of severe refracto ry tinnitus (31).

Trazodone, an atypical antidepressants, was also investigated in tinnitus patients but no signific ant reduction in tinnitus was obtained when compared to placebo (32). There is only one case report, described in the literature, of tinnitus treatment using a low dose of mirtazapine, with successful reduction of the symptom. We were able to demonstrate with our cases a significant reduction in tinnitus with prolonged mirtazapine treatment (33).

A Cochrane review accessed the effects of antidepressants on tinnitus and evaluated if the effect was due to direct a ction on tinnitus or if the benefit was secondary due to treatment of concomitant psychiatric disorders. Six trials were included, 610 patients. The overall results were insufficient to say antidepressants improve tinnitus (34). Tinnitus patients are very heterogeneous and tinnitus pathophysiology is multifactorial and complex, involving many different central pathways and neurotransmitters. This is probably the most significant reason for the difficulty to find a definite c ure for tinnitus. We believe antidepressants have their role in our patient´s treatment, as it acts on comorbid psychiatric symptoms and ameliorates tinnitus

annoyance and impact in daily life. We believe antidepressants have an important role in our patie nt´s treatment, as it acts on comorbid psychiatric symptoms and ameliorates tinnitus annoyance and impact in daily life. There may also be a direct effect of antidepressants on tinnitus central pathophysiological mechanisms. The limitations of our study sh ould be pointed out: the study was not placebo controlled; a larger sample would be desirable, as 14 patients is a limited number; and tinnitus was only measured using the VAS, no other scales or measurements were used to improve tinnitus analysis and the study lacked a control group. Yet, the follow up was long, 3 years, and the identified improvements were relevant and sustained. Finally, as stated before, there is, currently, no FDA approved pharmacological treatment for tinnitus. We believe our results are promising and should encourage further studies. Conclusion:

Our results demonstrate that patients with panic disorder and tinnitus treated with mirtazapine for more than 2 years obtained a successful, significant and sustained reduction on tinnitus a nnoyance, on the number of panic attacks as well as a significant decrease in the scores of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale and the Clinical Global impression scale.

5) Considerações Finais:

Os trabalhos descritos acima reforçam a relação do zumbido , e do incômodo relacionado ao sintoma , com transtornos psiquiátricos . Não há dúvidas de que a ansiedade piora o zumbido e o zumbido provoca ansiedade, ger ando assim um ciclo vicioso que resulta em significativa redução na qualidade de vida dos pacientes. Ainda, as evidencias de que o zumbido é gerado no cérebro, nas áreas auditivas e não auditivas, pri ncipal mente naquelas relacionadas ao sistema límbico, no s fazem acreditar que uma abordagem voltada para a neuromodulação, de forma a mudar a atividade neural anormal nessas áreas acometidas, seja, de fato, bastante promissora . Os resultados dos estudos que envolvem

estimulação magnética transcraniana no trata mento do zumbido têm dado motivos para otimismo , por ém é necessária a busca por estratégias mais eficazes . Acreditamos que o protocolo descrito em nosso trabalho abre o caminho para novos protocolos de EMTr. Outros modalidades de tratamento para o zumbido que modulem a resposta neural relacionada ao sintoma também são interessantes e merecem futuras investigações.
